intro: Agalinis pennellii, commonly known as the narrowleaf false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orobanchaceae family, which includes many parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as prairies and roadsides. Its flowers are tubular and range in color from white to pink, often attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Agalinis pennellii is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, lance-shaped leaves.
